story:
Story

When the business isn’t doing well, who saves the day? Are we at the mercy of those in charge? Or can we realize our power in those around us?

Our 10 episode comedy mini series hashes each side out as the staff of a struggling old town staple “Bangers”; clashes with a new duo of management know-it-alls determined to change everything for their dishonorable scheme. 

Inspired equally by lives of real servers who double as film creatives, Gratuity Not Included aims to depict a victory of the bunch over the few – the battle we each wage in real life. Only in fiction can we guarantee the bunch a win – or at least give the few a burger to the face! 

Shot in mockumentary style, Gratuity Not Included’s visual style deliberately evokes the feel of NBC’s Community, paying loving homage to the look of The Office and Parks and Recreation. 

In Front Of The Camera

Andrew Klasnic: Originally from Columbia, South Carolina. “I have been acting since I was 4! I began acting in local theater and really got serious with it around 8th grade. I knew I wanted to pursue acting as a career after playing Romeo in Romeo & Juliet my junior year of high school! It was exhilarating! I moved to LA right after high school, landed a few roles, and lived out there for 7 years. Now I am in Atlanta, GA acting! Right before I left LA, I was on 3 episodes of TruTV's LAFF TRACKS as a guest star! That was so much fun! And then I worked on two indie shorts recently, Crime Share (Chris & I were in it together!) and then a fun short called Weird Vibes!” Andrew Klasnic is also a published Author, his book “All-in-Skin” a guide to wellness. 

Megs Free: Originally from Fayetteville, GA. "I've been acting since high school, I also enjoy singing! I've done my fair share of theatre work also; Played Theodora in The Haunting of Hill House (stage production), Trixie in Last Call, Justine in The Love List (stage production)"

Chris June: Originally from Largo, Maryland. “I’ve always had an interest in the arts, although I didn’t begin taking acting seriously until I was cast in a webseries titled About Him Season 2 three years ago, I’ve landed many roles since up until my most recent role on ATL Homicide which releases this summer. I’ve been fortunate enough to work at the same restaurant as Drew, Megs and Ro. It’s amazing what you can accomplish around great people, I’m excited to be on this journey with them as creatives.” Chris also hosts the motivation/inspiration based book club he started at their job.

Tom Minier: Actor, Writer, Editor, Director is also a part of our supporting ensemble, we’re grateful to have him helping in front and behind the camera. 

Joshua Gilyard, Isabella De Leon, Payton Briggs Anderson: Supporting ensemble of Atlanta's finest players. This trio also has their hand in the service industry, but when they’re not serving you can find them on shows like Queen of the Ratchet, Sci- Fi thriller Once Again, as well as many other independent productions.

Behind The Camera 

Ronesha Strickland Writer/Director/Producer: A current student at the Savannah College of Art and Design originally from Maryland, she’s a writer and director and has been creating content for more than 6 years. “Before teaming up with these dope creators behind Gratuity Not Included, I wrote and directed two seasons of a webseries called Southern Hospitality. Both seasons are available on Amazon Prime and YouTube." Ronesha also met Drew, Megs and Chris while working together as servers.  

Palmer Rubin Editor/Director: "I originally hail from Harrington Park, New Jersey, but I've spent most of my life in Atlanta. I graduated from the Savannah College of Art and Design in 2017 majoring in Film & Television, and have been working as a filmmaker since 2013. I also began working on short sketches, but have worked on commercials, music videos, corporate videos and events, interviews, and editing documentaries and network television."

Irving Molefe Filmmaker/Composer: "I'm from Atlanta, GA. I've been a filmmaker for 6 years. I started out doing short sketches with friends on YouTube but then moved on to do real estate videography, corporate videos, internal training videos, and short films. I've been editing television for the past 2 years."

Joshua Gary Director of Photography: "I am from Atlanta. Born and Raised.  My most recent project that I've done is a feature film (that my brother and I directed and that I was the cinematographer for) called Half a Mile Out on the Night. Another project I've done recently is a music video for the artist Honey Harper that's on Sub Pop records."

Digital rewards save us shipping and save you space! 

How Your Contribution Will Help

Work on Gratuity Not Included began two months ago, and we are finally in the home stretch. With a gracious $25,000 we can finish progress on the film and release this beast into the wild!

 

Your donations help with: 

  • Locations
  • Wardrobe
  • Props
  • Promotion
  • Crew/Editing
  • Craft & Catering Services

Get excited about our unique perks!!!

$1 - thank you email
$10 - social media shout out
$50 - ebook of All in Skin by Andrew Klasnic
$100 - behind the scenes photo
$250 - personalized thank you video from a cast member
$500 - Google hangout with cast “Meet the Cast”
$1,000 - personalized easter egg dropped in a scene
$1,000 - how we created the series 
$2,500 - Associate Producer credit; digital copy of entire series with Q&A panel
$25,000 - Fund the project! Our eternal gratitude and all the stuff listed above AND you get that Executive Producer credit.

The Impact 

  • Being hit from both sides as service industry workers and film creatives, your contribution would go right to the heart of some of the most effected industry professionals during the COVID 19 crisis, keeping us going and productive.
  • We're all accomplished in more than one way and us continuing to work together in this capacity affects lives far beyond our cast.
  • We've adapted and kept the momentum going regardless of what's going on, that is exactly what we need right now. 

Risks & Challenges

Filmmaking is full of surprises and unexpected delays, which we've made our best effort to accommodate for when setting our timeline goals. The funds we are able to raise will go a long way in retaining the help needed to keep on schedule. With your support, we can get this film completed and out into the world as soon as possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute please share this page on your social media platforms or get it in front of more people!
  • Follow our Instagram @gratuitynotincluded
  • Follow our Facebook https://www.facebook.com/GratuityNotIncludedSer...
  • Follow our TikTok @gratuitynotincluded
  • Be sure to read our newsletter updates to watch our progress and for more opportunities to pitch in and help out.

And that's all there is to it.

Ronesha Strickland Writer/Director/Producer: A current student at the Savannah College of Art and Design originally from Maryland, she’s a writer and director and has been creating content for more than 6 years. “Before teaming up with these dope creators behind Gratuity Not Included, I wrote and directed two seasons of a webseries called Southern Hospitality. Both seasons are available on Amazon Prime and YouTube." Ronesha also met Drew, Megs and Chris while working together as servers.  

Palmer Rubin Editor/Director: "I originally hail from Harrington Park, New Jersey, but I've spent most of my life in Atlanta. I graduated from the Savannah College of Art and Design in 2017 majoring in Film & Television, and have been working as a filmmaker since 2013. I also began working on short sketches, but have worked on commercials, music videos, corporate videos and events, interviews, and editing documentaries and network television."

Irving Molefe Filmmaker/Composer: "I'm from Atlanta, GA. I've been a filmmaker for 6 years. I started out doing short sketches with friends on YouTube but then moved on to do real estate videography, corporate videos, internal training videos, and short films. I've been editing television for the past 2 years."

Joshua Gary Director of Photography: "I am from Atlanta. Born and Raised.  My most recent project that I've done is a feature film (that my brother and I directed and that I was the cinematographer for) called Half a Mile Out on the Night. Another project I've done recently is a music video for the artist Honey Harper that's on Sub Pop records."
Digital rewards save us shipping and save you space! 
How Your Contribution Will Help
Work on Gratuity Not Included began two months ago, and we are finally in the home stretch. With a gracious $25,000 we can finish progress on the film and release this beast into the wild!
 

Your donations help with: 

Locations
Wardrobe
Props
Promotion
Crew/Editing
Craft & Catering Services

Get excited about our unique perks!!!
$1 - thank you email$10 - social media shout out$50 - ebook of All in Skin by Andrew Klasnic$100 - behind the scenes photo$250 - personalized thank you video from a cast member$500 - Google hangout with cast “Meet the Cast”$1,000 - personalized easter egg dropped in a scene$1,000 - how we created the series $2,500 - Associate Producer credit; digital copy of entire series with Q&A panel$25,000 - Fund the project! Our eternal gratitude and all the stuff listed above AND you get that Executive Producer credit.

The Impact 

Being hit from both sides as service industry workers and film creatives, your contribution would go right to the heart of some of the most effected industry professionals during the COVID 19 crisis, keeping us going and productive.
We're all accomplished in more than one way and us continuing to work together in this capacity affects lives far beyond our cast.
We've adapted and kept the momentum going regardless of what's going on, that is exactly what we need right now. 


Risks & Challenges
Filmmaking is full of surprises and unexpected delays, which we've made our best effort to accommodate for when setting our timeline goals. The funds we are able to raise will go a long way in retaining the help needed to keep on schedule. With your support, we can get this film completed and out into the world as soon as possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute please share this page on your social media platforms or get it in front of more people!
Follow our Instagram @gratuitynotincluded
Follow our Facebook https://www.facebook.com/GratuityNotIncludedSer...

Follow our TikTok @gratuitynotincluded
Be sure to read our newsletter updates to watch our progress and for more opportunities to pitch in and help out.

And that's all there is to it.

story: This campaign is to help create our web series. It is called Hellacious Affair and it is created and written by David-Henry Bennett and Lora King. Both of us have attend or still currently attend Academy of Art University. The show is a spy comedy that follows Henry, the top spy agent who happens to be very clumsy and sometimes aloof, as he picks his new partner, Lorie, who is a bit neurotic and very new, as the get to know one another and solve their first case together. They work together to protect the world from a dangerous drug that is about to be released that is set to kill millions of people. Help us make and produce this show. All funds will be toward the production, from materials to hiring talent and crew. It is a completely collaborative project that is meant to bring entertainment and showcase a diverse group of characters, that are from different races, sexual orientations, and backgrounds. Thank you and welcome to our journey.

story:
Short Summary

As humans, we live according to social rules that we've come to accept as the norm. But what if you came from a world where people lived in a completely different way? Where interactions and relationships were purely utilitarian, and showing emotion was frowned upon? What would you make of dating, friendship, and social conventions? That's exactly the situation our protagonist, Lex Kepler, finds herself in.

 

Alien explorer and scientist, Lex Kepler, comes from a very logical and science-oriented society. Xalax, her colleague, is creative and intuitive; basically the black sheep of their race, and the total opposite of Lex. The captain has assigned Lex and Xalax to study the human race from a sociological perspective, a subject matter that's totally out of Lex's element.  

 

The aliens are enrolled in a university where they pretend to be brother and sister, and they cultivate friendships with several humans. In the beginning of the series, Lex and Xalax have a hard time working together. Lex views Xalax as an incompetent slacker, and Xalax feels that Lex is too stringent. As time goes on, they develop a deep bond. They go from pretending to be brother and sister to forming an emotional connection that's equivalent to a sibling relationship.

 

                                             

 

My Human Experience gives us an outsider's perspective on our society today and what it means to be human. Lex and Xalax learn about our society and the human condition (relationships, creativity, family, social media, pop culture, current trends, and friendship) -- and in the process, they remind the audience about the things that are truly important. Their misadventures are sure to make you laugh along the way.

 

This is a series that was created by two women, and one of our most important priorities is to give a voice to women (including women of color) and others with underrepresented perspectives. The show features a woman scientist as the lead character, and her human friend is a woman who is earning a graduate level degree in the sciences. Because women in STEM careers are still woefully underrepresented in popular media, we feel it's important to put female scientists front and center.

 

 

The Team:

 

Aimee Dansereau - Show's Creator/Writer

Aimee Dansereau is a screenwriter and script reader, and a lifelong sci-fi enthusiast. One of her sci-fi TV scripts came in 1st place for the Television Category of the WeScreenplay Diverse Voices Contest.  She and Sarah Cooke were finalists (one of the top 10) in the Creative World Awards Screenwriting Competition. Aimee has also received high placements in other contests such as Screencraft, the WeScreenplay TV Pilot Contest, the Shore Scripts Contest, the Emerging Screenwriters "Shoot Your Sizzle Competition," and the Pulsar Sci-fi Screenwriting Competition. One of her short stories received an honorable mention in the 78th Annual Writer's Digest Writing Competition. She has an MFA in Writing.

 

Sarah Cooke - Show's Creator/Writer

Sarah Cooke is a lifelong fan of science fiction and fandom. She started watching Star Trek with her parents at age five and her love of geeky things grew from there. She and Aimee were finalists (one of the top 10) in the Creative World Awards Screenwriting Competition, and placed in the WeScreenplay Television Competition and the ScreenCraft Pilot Launch Competition. She is a blogger for Marvel Entertainment and has written for DC Comics, Women Write About Comics, Fembot, Women Working, Comic Book Resources, and more. She has an MFA in Creative Writing.

 

Jenn Page - Director

Jenn Page is an accomplished, multi-award winning feature and series director who was selected by Take the Lead as one of the "50 Women Who Can Change the World in Media & Entertainment." She's filmed projects for/with internationally known brands such as Marvel's Agents of Shield, The Mindy Project, The Voice, and more. Her work includes the award-winning comedy musical feature film “Waiting in the Wings” starring Lee Meriwether and Shirley Jones, the award-winning musical comedy series “My Two Black Girlfriends,” the award-winning dramatic rock opera “The Breakout,” and the International Academy of Web Television’s live awards show hosted by Tony award winner Roger Bart.  Most recently, she completed “Playing with Beethoven,” a feature film starring Kadeem Hardison and Shannon Elizabeth. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're asking for $15,000, which is the minimum of what we need to be able to film the 1st episode. The funds go toward securing a talented cast & crew (and feeding them during filming hours), quality costumes, set & props, location and insurance costs, and any other filmmaking expenses that could arise. 

Check out our list of out-of-this-world perks to see what cool things you can receive from contributing!

 

The Impact

Every contribution and campaign share gets us closer to our dream of turning our sci-fi comedy script into a fun, and engaging digital series for you to watch!

We wrote this as something fun for us to do as friends, but after entering it into contests, sharing it with industry professionals, and seeing how well received it was, and how funny people found it, we were inspired to have it produced as an online series. The original script placed as a finalist (one of the top 10) in the Creative World Awards Contest, and has placed decently in several other contests such as Screencraft and WeScreenplay.

As mostly writers, we didn't feel we had the experience to direct it ourselves so we reached out to an accomplished, multi-award winning director, Jenn Page, who was enthusiastic about the script. She and her multi-award winning production team, Heart on Fire Productions, will take our script and make it into a professional looking digital series. We are elated to find such an exceptional team to work with! 

 

Risks & Challenges

There are always risks in filmmaking. In fact, taking creative risks is often a necessity if you want  a final product that will truly resonate with audiences. There are a lot of moving pieces with a film or, in our case, a web series. Everything from cast and crew to equipment, location, and food has to be coordinated in detail. But we've got a team that's great at organization and we're confident we will make this happen. All we need is the funding, so that all the awesome people on our team can do their thing.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate, there's still other ways you can help us reach our goal. Please help us spread the word by posting and sharing links of our video and campaign page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or anywhere else you virtually or physically inhabit. Word of mouth is also very helpful.

 

Our FB & Twitter handles are: @MHESeries

 

https://www.facebook.com/MHESeries/

 

https://twitter.com/MHESeries

story:
Little Roar and His Big Family will be a webseries for preschool and young school aged children that follows the adventures of Little Roar, a five-year-old Tyrannosaurus Rex, his sister, Tiny Claw, and their two moms, Mommy and Mama Rex. Together, with a diverse cast of characters, the young dinosaurs will learn lessons about kindness and teamwork, as well as their ABC’s and 123’s.

Elaine Wall is the creator and a co-writer for the series. She and her wife are parents to a 3-year-old and 4-year-old.  When their kids were two, and songs like Baby Shark and Finger Family were the rage at story times around town, Elaine began to look around for nursery rhymes or children’s television or webseries that depicted families like their own to share with her kids, but found none.  And once she began to pay attention, she noticed that many other kinds of families, families through adoption or foster care, single parent or grandparent lead families, families with differently abled members, as well as LGBTQ+ families, were also hard to find. Soon after, the idea for Little Roar and His Big Family was born. Two T. rex siblings and their two moms; Grandpa Brachiosaurus and his grandson Olly; the Pterodactyl twins, Hank and Frank, and their single mom Ms. Dactyl; the Stegosauruses, Bruce and Judy, who live with their mom and dad, Sally and Bob Triceratops; as well as many others help demonstrate to young children that love and kindness is what makes a family great.

A group of artists have come together to produce the show with the help of Wolverine Farm Publishing, a 501c3 literary and arts nonprofit. They include artist Moby Donigian, animator and graphic artist Justin Maul, voice artist Hanna Doreen Brown, writer Melissa Mitchell, and the band Trash Cat, comprised of Brian and Mary Claxton and Hayden Farr.

Funding raised from this campaign will help us produce season one.  Can't contribute at this time? Please consider sharing this on social media, or with your friends and family.

Thanks for your support!

story:
Short Summary

Times are tough, the news is horrifying, and we are all in desperate need of fun and entertainment and unadulterated ridiculousness. Also people like space.

Burlesque kingpin Doc Wasabassco and science enthusiast Kat Green invite you to join us as we pull together our varied interests and Rolodex of fascinating human beings to create a talk show for the future age:  Outer Space with Doc Wasabassco. One part talk show, one part science fiction adventure, all parts absurd.

With your help we'll be able to produce a web series chronicling the adventures of the Captain and crew of the spaceship UAS Dorothy Fontana, 200 years into the future, and the beings and entertainers they encounter in the far reaches of the galaxy.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the thing, we've already sunk a bunch of our own money and countless person-hours into building sets and models and and costumes, and we have a laundry list of people who's services we'll need to acquire to realize our objective. The final product is going to be free to view, so we're asking for upfront help to make this the best space-themed talk show we can.

We've designed our perks to get you involved, to make this show as much about you and your love of sci-fi and science and nonsense as about our own. We want you to be able to tell your friends you helped - or maybe appeared on - a science fiction web series.

We've set our goal at $10,000. That's going to reimburse us for what we've spent already and allow us to pay for the facilities, personnel, and equipment we need to create episodes of the show.

If we don't reach our goal we'll still spend what funds we do raise on the show - we'll just use more duct tape to solve problems, less cool aliens and stuff, and we'll make fewer episodes. If we raise MORE than our goal, we'll use the funds for cooler stuff and to help pay the rent and feed ourselves.

The Impact

Look, our mission here is to add a little joy to your life and ours, and to balance the grim news cycle with a little pure unadulterated fun - and we want to do it on a spaceship, because who doesn't love sci-fi stupidity? We're not saving the world here but we do want to entertain you and we promise to pull together everything our experience has taught us and to utilize everything we know to amuse you as much as we amuse ourselves. Sound good?

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times are tough right now. If you're unable to financially contribute you can still assist us by helping getting the word out about this campaign! Share this campaign with your friends and followers using the Indiegogo share tools. Make it personal by telling them why you'd like to see our show.

Thanks so much!

story:
Logline:

  • Seven passionate partisans from both sides of the border and a dual-citizen moderator look for common ground by discussing issues from a 2LGBTQ+ perspective.

         “CROSSOVER. Finding Common Ground. Discussing Common Sense.”

 

BACKGROUND:

  • The full acronym for the community is lengthy.  However, it is important to understand what each of the letters mean.  There has never been a formal acronym, as it constantly evolves and considerations like region and local understanding have played significant roles in determining the local acronyms that are used.  With that, some common forms of the acronym include:

         2LGBTQQIAAP+

         2-Spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, intersex, asexual, ally, pansexual with the plus sign denoting “more” or “additional” as well as HIV Positive.  CROSSOVER will use 2LGBTQ+.

 

CONCEPT:

  • A combination political and current affairs show with Co-hosts representing diverse gender, racial and sexual identities (2LGBTQ+). Each Co-host represents, unofficially, a major political party in the United States or Canada. American Co-hosts represent the Republican Party, the Democratic Party and the Libertarian Party. Canadian Co-hosts represent the Conservative Party of Canada, the Green Party of Canada, the Liberal Party of Canada and Canada’s New Democratic Party.

 

  • There will be no official financial involvement or participation by any of the political parties; the moderator and co-hosts will maintain editorial control over the show’s content.

 

  • PILOT EPISODE: A pilot episode of CROSSOVER will be filmed JANUARY 21, 2018 at an Air Canada hangar at Toronto’s Pearson international Airport, with the anchor cast and moderator and will be available for review shortly after.

 

  • PHASE I will broadcast online each Sunday evening, twice filmed in each of the co-hosts respective cities, and twice each month filmed in the “on location” city outlined in the “Schedule” portion of this document.  The approximate length of each episode will be 40 minutes airing both online and on Air Canada's in-flight entertainment as well as other platforms to be announced.
  • PHASE II will broadcast 60-minutes using the same format as Phase I, except via live television broadcast as the primary medium.
  • PHASE I (ONLINE/AIR CANADA IN-FLIGHT ENTERTAINMENT) LAUNCH DATE: MARCH 25, 2018
  • PHASE II (BROADCAST TELEVISION) PROPOSED LAUNCH DATE: FALL 2019

 

TARGET AUDIENCE:

  • The target audience, while wholly inclusive of the 2LGBTQ+ community, will not exclude anyone.  The show will draw interest, viewership and support from multiple communities and individuals across North America, and likely from around the world.  Our confirmed partnership with Air Canada as the Canadian Air Carrier also brings a potentially larger mainstream audience through Air Canada’s in-flight entertainment, a medium also being sought with an American Air Carrier.

 

OUR GOAL:

CROSSOVER seeks to combine the cultural power of mass communication with the healing power of 2LGBTQ+ identities as an agent of social transformation.

 

We believe that existing media narratives are not always complete, and that voices like ours have something relevant to offer in terms of a call for mutual respect and the unity that comes from prioritizing diversity.

 

In other words, the world is filled with political partisans, and our aim is to show what it looks like when people are nice, or at least “politely sassy” as they cross-over multiple boundaries.

 

There are many educational benefits that come from setting aside the partisan animosity traditionally seen as an impasse, without setting aside our shared, underlying motives for a peaceful, prosperous world and ideas for achieving them:

 

  • Increased understanding of Canadian and US politics by people of both nations
  • Restored public confidence in the electoral process as a vehicle for positive change
  • Facilitate meaningful electoral choices not driven by fear or character assassination
  • Respect for the relevance of 2LGBTQ+ voices to issues beyond gender & sexual identity politics

2LGBTQ+ people have historically been known as voices of healing and unity in our communities. Without trying to generalize, we can confidently say that our unique lived experiences provide a lens through which the value of finding common ground is seen as an opportunity for the famed creative spirit of our people to shine through opportunities including:

  • “Crossing over” segments where partisans switch roles to defend and illuminate one another’s positions in unexpected ways
  • Introspective segments where partisans are offered space to critique areas for improvement within their own parties
  • Explanations and guided tours from Parliament Hill (Ottawa, Ontario) and Capitol Hill (Washington, DC), inviting viewers to learn with the Co-hosts about the governments of each nation, and episodes filmed in each of the Co-hosts respective cities.
  • Guest appearances by local activists, candidates and elected 2LGBTQ+ people from each nation
  • “Wholesome Family Discussion” segments where Co-hosts debate current, politically charged issues or scandals within the loving context of queer-culturally traditional “snark”
  • “Fake News Bulletin” segments where dubious material is examined and consensus regarding its veracity is reached
  • “Quiz Show” segments to present educational material in the form of entertainment
  • Audience participation through social media and contests to win a chance to appear on the show

Leading by example, CROSSOVER hopes to set a tone of mutual respect and camaraderie across partisan and international boundaries, helping to pave the way for a global spirit of peaceful dialogue to benefit everyone on the planet.  The tone of CROSSOVER will, in many ways, be opposite to most pundit shows.

 

While certain elements of our program, as currently planned, may not strictly fall within existing media funding categories, in our view, CROSSOVER broadly complies with the spirit of many funding criteria in that:

  1. One of our two co-producers is a Canadian citizen, and the other an American citizen, each holding an integral part in determining what content will appear on the show.  Our Canadian Co-Producer, as does the U.S. Cp-Producer, hold veto over content proposed by others, and is prepared to use his power to exclude any content that would devalue the production for either country, or otherwise run counter to the ideals behind most major funder’s policies.

 

  1. CROSSOVER’s American Co-Producer has visited Canada more than two dozen times over the past fourteen years and has researched and published papers on Canadian politics and shares in a commitment that the Canadian nature of our production be preserved and highlighted, often a disadvantage many Canadian productions encounter.

 

  1. In each and every episode, five of CROSSOVER’s eight cast members (including our dual-citizen moderator) are Canadian citizens.  Of the remaining three, one regularly appears on Canadian television (on networks such as the CBC), and the other two share the vision that the show’s content reflect all of the markings of a cross-border production.

 

  1. While points of view will inevitably be expressed in CROSSOVER’s exploration and discussion of Canadian issues, no single point of view will be assigned a higher importance or level of validity over another (though all content presented will have a factual basis), due to the representation of all of Canada’s political parties.  This falls in line with a core mission of the show, which is to educate holistically about Canadian issues, and not to propagandize.

 

Moreover, the bi-national nature of CROSSOVER makes us better positioned to promote the spirit of the major funding policies than a traditional, strictly “Canada-only” production would, in the following respects:

 

  1. Content related to the United States, bearing high salience around the world, will be presented, but done mostly by Canadians (in partnership with their American co-hosts) and with a Canadian perspective; coverage of U.S. and world events with a Canadian “twist” is currently available nowhere else outside of the domestic Canadian market.  The existence of a show like CROSSOVER changes this unfortunate reality.

 

  1. U.S.-based content will be presented to our audience alongside our Canadian content, giving the large U.S. viewer base immediate access to information and educational material on Canada, and over the long term, will promote interest and commerce in, and affinity for, Canada among U.S. viewers.  Exposure to Canadian culture and perspectives for U.S. viewers will be facilitated throughout.

 

  1. The broadcast medium chosen for CROSSOVER enables our cast to reach a worldwide audience, who in turn, will also be introduced to Canadian perspectives on issues important to them and in ways that may not reach these audiences who are often inundated with broadcasts from the United States

 

DRAFT CONTENT/SHOW TOPICS:

 

  • Similar to high-school debate club, Co-hosts will express their views as they relate to their respective parties on issues/topics, but also each episode will have two Co-hosts (varied by episode) who will defend the other Co-hosts position in a “crossing over” segment.

 

  • Co-hosts will be asked to provide critiques of their own party, ways to make their party better in the direction they would like or believe their party should be taking on different issues.

 

  • Two episodes will include explanations and guided tours from Parliament Hill and Capitol Hill representatives of the respective legislative buildings, and electoral explanations, including explanation of things like swing states and ridings

 

  • 2LGBTQ+ and allies/elected Legislators will join the show, including US and Canadian Ambassadors

 

  • The political “Coattails” between Canada and the United States

 

  • “So What?” segment – how does the issue we are talking about relate to the 2LGBTQ+ community?

 

  • 1-minute pre-taped, cohost monologue (Rants-Rick Mercer style) https://youtu.be/gFgPX0hnNfA

 

  • Interviews with local 2LGBTQ+ individuals in various co-hosts districts

 

  • Invite viewers, including rural, to comment by social media including tweet, skype, email etc…

 

  • "Wholesome Family Discussion” For each filming, the show identifies either a salient, politically- charged issue for which differences are irreconcilable (abortion, gun control), discussing a recent news story on the topic, or an instance of scandal (Mueller probe, sexual misconduct e.g. Larry Craig's foot-tapping, Weinergate), a controversial tweet or other tabloid-style issue that elicits a s, strong response.  All Co-hosts (and guests, if present) contribute in one 3-minute moderated block.  This may be the least "serious" segment; if any mudslinging does occur, it will likely be here.

 

  • “Fake News Bulletin” When a co-host encounters source material that is dubious, they are encouraged to share it with the other co-hosts to discuss its veracity.  If a consensus determines the material is false, it can be used for a “Fake News Bulletin” segment.

 

  • Different dialects and mannerisms, both in government and in society.
  • Gender fluidity in politics
  • Op-ed style segments favoring one party platform/position may at times be used less in favor of engaging the viewers with questions, and encouraging them to create and ask their own
  • "Quiz show" segments of other co-hosts and guests using a variety of game formats
  • Periodic "gaymer"/nerd culture segments to include perspectives of 18-29 age group
  • North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
  • 2018 USA Midterms and 2019 Canadian Federal Election
  • RapidFire segment
story_txt:
Logline:
Seven passionate partisans from both sides of the border and a dual-citizen moderator look for common ground by discussing issues from a 2LGBTQ+ perspective.
         “CROSSOVER. Finding Common Ground. Discussing Common Sense.”
 
BACKGROUND:
The full acronym for the community is lengthy.  However, it is important to understand what each of the letters mean.  There has never been a formal acronym, as it constantly evolves and considerations like region and local understanding have played significant roles in determining the local acronyms that are used.  With that, some common forms of the acronym include:
         2LGBTQQIAAP+
         2-Spirit, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, intersex, asexual, ally, pansexual with the plus sign denoting “more” or “additional” as well as HIV Positive.  CROSSOVER will use 2LGBTQ+.
 
CONCEPT:
A combination political and current affairs show with Co-hosts representing diverse gender, racial and sexual identities (2LGBTQ+). Each Co-host represents, unofficially, a major political party in the United States or Canada. American Co-hosts represent the Republican Party, the Democratic Party and the Libertarian Party. Canadian Co-hosts represent the Conservative Party of Canada, the Green Party of Canada, the Liberal Party of Canada and Canada’s New Democratic Party.
 
There will be no official financial involvement or participation by any of the political parties; the moderator and co-hosts will maintain editorial control over the show’s content.
 
PILOT EPISODE: A pilot episode of CROSSOVER will be filmed JANUARY 21, 2018 at an Air Canada hangar at Toronto’s Pearson international Airport, with the anchor cast and moderator and will be available for review shortly after.
 

PHASE I will broadcast online each Sunday evening, twice filmed in each of the co-hosts respective cities, and twice each month filmed in the “on location” city outlined in the “Schedule” portion of this document.  The approximate length of each episode will be 40 minutes airing both online and on Air Canada's in-flight entertainment as well as other platforms to be announced.
PHASE II will broadcast 60-minutes using the same format as Phase I, except via live television broadcast as the primary medium.

PHASE I (ONLINE/AIR CANADA IN-FLIGHT ENTERTAINMENT) LAUNCH DATE: MARCH 25, 2018
PHASE II (BROADCAST TELEVISION) PROPOSED LAUNCH DATE: FALL 2019
 
TARGET AUDIENCE:
The target audience, while wholly inclusive of the 2LGBTQ+ community, will not exclude anyone.  The show will draw interest, viewership and support from multiple communities and individuals across North America, and likely from around the world.  Our confirmed partnership with Air Canada as the Canadian Air Carrier also brings a potentially larger mainstream audience through Air Canada’s in-flight entertainment, a medium also being sought with an American Air Carrier.
 
OUR GOAL:
CROSSOVER seeks to combine the cultural power of mass communication with the healing power of 2LGBTQ+ identities as an agent of social transformation.
 
We believe that existing media narratives are not always complete, and that voices like ours have something relevant to offer in terms of a call for mutual respect and the unity that comes from prioritizing diversity.
 
In other words, the world is filled with political partisans, and our aim is to show what it looks like when people are nice, or at least “politely sassy” as they cross-over multiple boundaries.
 
There are many educational benefits that come from setting aside the partisan animosity traditionally seen as an impasse, without setting aside our shared, underlying motives for a peaceful, prosperous world and ideas for achieving them:
 

Increased understanding of Canadian and US politics by people of both nations
Restored public confidence in the electoral process as a vehicle for positive change
Facilitate meaningful electoral choices not driven by fear or character assassination
Respect for the relevance of 2LGBTQ+ voices to issues beyond gender & sexual identity politics

2LGBTQ+ people have historically been known as voices of healing and unity in our communities. Without trying to generalize, we can confidently say that our unique lived experiences provide a lens through which the value of finding common ground is seen as an opportunity for the famed creative spirit of our people to shine through opportunities including:
“Crossing over” segments where partisans switch roles to defend and illuminate one another’s positions in unexpected ways
Introspective segments where partisans are offered space to critique areas for improvement within their own parties
Explanations and guided tours from Parliament Hill (Ottawa, Ontario) and Capitol Hill (Washington, DC), inviting viewers to learn with the Co-hosts about the governments of each nation, and episodes filmed in each of the Co-hosts respective cities.
Guest appearances by local activists, candidates and elected 2LGBTQ+ people from each nation
“Wholesome Family Discussion” segments where Co-hosts debate current, politically charged issues or scandals within the loving context of queer-culturally traditional “snark”

“Fake News Bulletin” segments where dubious material is examined and consensus regarding its veracity is reached
“Quiz Show” segments to present educational material in the form of entertainment
Audience participation through social media and contests to win a chance to appear on the show

Leading by example, CROSSOVER hopes to set a tone of mutual respect and camaraderie across partisan and international boundaries, helping to pave the way for a global spirit of peaceful dialogue to benefit everyone on the planet.  The tone of CROSSOVER will, in many ways, be opposite to most pundit shows.
 
While certain elements of our program, as currently planned, may not strictly fall within existing media funding categories, in our view, CROSSOVER broadly complies with the spirit of many funding criteria in that:
One of our two co-producers is a Canadian citizen, and the other an American citizen, each holding an integral part in determining what content will appear on the show.  Our Canadian Co-Producer, as does the U.S. Cp-Producer, hold veto over content proposed by others, and is prepared to use his power to exclude any content that would devalue the production for either country, or otherwise run counter to the ideals behind most major funder’s policies.
 
CROSSOVER’s American Co-Producer has visited Canada more than two dozen times over the past fourteen years and has researched and published papers on Canadian politics and shares in a commitment that the Canadian nature of our production be preserved and highlighted, often a disadvantage many Canadian productions encounter.
 
In each and every episode, five of CROSSOVER’s eight cast members (including our dual-citizen moderator) are Canadian citizens.  Of the remaining three, one regularly appears on Canadian television (on networks such as the CBC), and the other two share the vision that the show’s content reflect all of the markings of a cross-border production.
 
While points of view will inevitably be expressed in CROSSOVER’s exploration and discussion of Canadian issues, no single point of view will be assigned a higher importance or level of validity over another (though all content presented will have a factual basis), due to the representation of all of Canada’s political parties.  This falls in line with a core mission of the show, which is to educate holistically about Canadian issues, and not to propagandize.
 
Moreover, the bi-national nature of CROSSOVER makes us better positioned to promote the spirit of the major funding policies than a traditional, strictly “Canada-only” production would, in the following respects:
 
Content related to the United States, bearing high salience around the world, will be presented, but done mostly by Canadians (in partnership with their American co-hosts) and with a Canadian perspective; coverage of U.S. and world events with a Canadian “twist” is currently available nowhere else outside of the domestic Canadian market.  The existence of a show like CROSSOVER changes this unfortunate reality.
 
U.S.-based content will be presented to our audience alongside our Canadian content, giving the large U.S. viewer base immediate access to information and educational material on Canada, and over the long term, will promote interest and commerce in, and affinity for, Canada among U.S. viewers.  Exposure to Canadian culture and perspectives for U.S. viewers will be facilitated throughout.
 
The broadcast medium chosen for CROSSOVER enables our cast to reach a worldwide audience, who in turn, will also be introduced to Canadian perspectives on issues important to them and in ways that may not reach these audiences who are often inundated with broadcasts from the United States

Similar to high-school debate club, Co-hosts will express their views as they relate to their respective parties on issues/topics, but also each episode will have two Co-hosts (varied by episode) who will defend the other Co-hosts position in a “crossing over” segment.
 
Co-hosts will be asked to provide critiques of their own party, ways to make their party better in the direction they would like or believe their party should be taking on different issues.
 
Two episodes will include explanations and guided tours from Parliament Hill and Capitol Hill representatives of the respective legislative buildings, and electoral explanations, including explanation of things like swing states and ridings
 
2LGBTQ+ and allies/elected Legislators will join the show, including US and Canadian Ambassadors
 
The political “Coattails” between Canada and the United States
 
“So What?” segment – how does the issue we are talking about relate to the 2LGBTQ+ community?

Interviews with local 2LGBTQ+ individuals in various co-hosts districts
 
Invite viewers, including rural, to comment by social media including tweet, skype, email etc…
 
"Wholesome Family Discussion” For each filming, the show identifies either a salient, politically- charged issue for which differences are irreconcilable (abortion, gun control), discussing a recent news story on the topic, or an instance of scandal (Mueller probe, sexual misconduct e.g. Larry Craig's foot-tapping, Weinergate), a controversial tweet or other tabloid-style issue that elicits a s, strong response.  All Co-hosts (and guests, if present) contribute in one 3-minute moderated block.  This may be the least "serious" segment; if any mudslinging does occur, it will likely be here.
 
“Fake News Bulletin” When a co-host encounters source material that is dubious, they are encouraged to share it with the other co-hosts to discuss its veracity.  If a consensus determines the material is false, it can be used for a “Fake News Bulletin” segment.
 

Different dialects and mannerisms, both in government and in society.
Gender fluidity in politics
Op-ed style segments favoring one party platform/position may at times be used less in favor of engaging the viewers with questions, and encouraging them to create and ask their own

story:
We're already halfway there.

We have already filmed several episodes, this campaign will help finish up the season. Take a look at some of what we've shot:
 

 

We want to finish telling this story and for that we need your help. 

We have an entire cast and crew that has been steadfast in their support. This campaign allows us to pay them for the awesome work they've been doing.

We already have the gear, with $15000 we can pay for our crew, cast and most importantly, our locations, which in a show about realty, really stack up. 

 

Other Ways to Contribute

Maybe you're cash poor, but you can't live without our show, we get it. We're going through the same struggle. Here's other ways you can help:

*Our show involves about two dozen apartments in the first season, so if you have an amazing New York City apartment and you're cool letting us film there for a day (We have insurance) you can make a huge difference for our production.

*You are willing to contribute post production services (CGI, coloring, sound design).

story:
Why Support This Project?

This web series is created by emerging film artists, writers, illustrators, photographers, and aims to engage with a diverse audience. Your donations support up-and-coming Canadian artists and a story focused on not only making you laugh (our number one goal is to make you laugh) but also a story that touches on contemporary issues of inequality, social structures, politics, race and sexuality all with a funny twist that is meant to be self-aware and reflexive. Further, our intention for this pilot episode is to pitch the comedy series at the 2018 Just for Laughs Comedy Festival in Montreal. We want to continue making this show, but we need your help to get it started!

Meet The Turtleneck Creative & Production Team!

Samantha Rousseau - Creator and Director

I have always been into warm, cozy turtleneck sweaters. Donning the turtleneck first as a young adolescent, this is when I first began to realize that the suffocating nature of the turtleneck was a minor inconvenience in return for the encompassing warmth that such a garment can provide in retaliation against cold Canadian winters. Now, in my early twenties, I am fully committed to bringing audiences the same love and affection I have for the turtleneck sweater to this web series and the variety of quirky, emotional and off-the-wall characters that I hope you guys fall in love with.

I graduated from Queen’s University Film and Media department. This is also where I met a majority of this incredible team behind Turtleneck.

Eric Tisch (aka Andy) – Writer/Actor 

My life motto is the fairly common idiom “You are what you eat”. I interpret this as an instruction to only consume the finest works of art to ensure that my creative excretions are supreme art works themselves. I am thrilled that I was given the opportunity to chronicle my experiences as a part of this society as one of the writers on the series, and I have sought to conduct my pen in a fashionable manner that behooves the memories it details. I was also given the opportunity to portray myself in the series, a privilege I do not take lightly. As an actor, I chew only the finest of scenery, which is why this project with its particularly delicious setting is so obviously appealing. I treat this endeavour not only as a reflection of myself, but equally of the carefully chosen diet that has crossed my perfectionist palette. Thanks to the efforts of the cast and crew to bring my stories to life, I feel confident that you will be enraptured and enlightened

Fenton Isaacs - Director of Photography 

I'm Fenton and I will be the cinematographer for The Turtleneck Society Web Series. I'm excited to capture the elegance, the grace and the beauty of these characters in a picturesque way. Not only am I excited about making this series look great but I'm also stoked to work on the comedy aspect. How to translate the humour in the script and onto the screen and how to shoot this in a way that reflects the prestige of the club and how they wish others to see them but also who they really are at their core which is superficial, insecure, ridiculous and flawed. 

Jordana Green - Production Designer/Illustrator

Jordana’s ideal turtleneck would be one that can be worn while consuming copious amounts of coffee. Its colour would match, or at the very least complement the colour in an artistic way. When at Queen’s University, the lack of properly coordinated coffee-clothing combinations concerned her. Being in the art department of The Turtleneck Society as production designer is a far more comfortable position in this respect, and the lack of appalling exposed necks is just a bonus.

Danielle Bolick - Lead Animator/Illustrator 

Every time I wear a turtleneck, it feels like a noose is tightening just a little more around my neck; thereby bringing me closer to death. As a masochistic individual, that sweet and deadly embrace comforts me.

As an animator I wanna be famous, but like how voice actors or authors are famous. I wanna be able to go to conventions and sign stuff and meet people that are way cooler than me but somehow like my work and feel famous but then drive out to Robertitos taco shop for lunch in my Nissan Cube and not have anybody recognize me as I scarf down my chicken burrito and spill hot sauce on my shirt. Animating for The Turtleneck Society, and bringing these characters to life, gave me absolute joy. It was the closest thing I could be to being in front of the camera without having to actually be in front of the camera. Also the free wine was some good quality stuff. Thanks y’all!

Jason Fung - Music Supervisor 

Hello! My name is Jason Fung, and I am in charge of music for The Turtleneck Web Series. The decision to record a soundtrack of entirely classical music for piano has been an interesting challenge for me. One wants to find something that will ironically embody the 'hoity-toitiness' of the club, yet provide a pleasant and varied listening experience with the inclusion of a few 'not-quite-so-popular favorites'. This has all been a terrifically fun experience for me, and I hope you will find the series to your liking.

Maria Vlasova - Unit Publicist 

Dear Maria,

As you embark on the journey of being Unit Publicist on The Turtleneck Society, you should remember the experiences you’ve encountered in this great journey of life. Be it as a graduate from Queen’s University, a socials Guru at Wax, or that time you spilled the sunflower oil and had to settle for tequila. You have matured like a fine wine, and now it is time to savour the oaky undertones that you have imbued into your position.

Sincerely,

Maria from the future

Meet the (real life) Turtleneck Society

Gregory Guevara - Alain Improviste,The President 

Existential dread is a humorous thing -- one day your mind screams "AHHHHHH!" and the next it barely musters an "aHhHhHhHh?" When I'm not drowning in the pain of existence I drown instead on the finest of wines. Not out of desire to escape the pain, you understand, but because I genuinely don't like wine. The bitter taste makes my lips tense up and frown involuntarily and in turn furthers my own bitterness towards the world. Why did I pay $80 for this high-class drink I don't even enjoy? I drink the wine out of self-loathing. Haha, just kidding! That was just a bit of a taste of my poetry. I'm really quite a happy person. I play a fellow with some slammin' poetry: the president of the Turtleneck Society. Grab some wine and enjoy. Or don't, the void is indifferent.

Jackson Fielding - Søren von Sørenson, Cultural Attaché

A turtleneck was never something I enjoyed nor sought in my life. Clunky, itchy and often too warm, I made a conscious choice throughout my young life to avoid, shun and on occasions lambaste. It wasn't until I was forcibly gifted a turtleneck that I begrudgingly began to wear them. And while now, three years later, much of that original scorn remains, I put up with it because that's what an artist does. And yes, I am an artist. Not in the literal sense, but the metaphorical. I learnt what 'metaphorical' meant at Queen's university where I went to school and where this whole turtleneck trouble began. And here we are now, making something explicitly centered around the turtleneck top. That's okay, I suppose.

Alexandra Lloyd - Elizabeth "Lizzie", Club Photographer 

Alexandra Lloyd, playing the role of Lizzie, could not be more excited to be a part of such a wonderful project! As someone living on a university student’s budget, Alexandra is looking forward to portraying a character who is a true bougie-ass b*tch. In addition for her passion for the arts, Alexandra loves ranting about the cisheteropatriarchy and using the third person to discuss herself. Alexandra currently resides in one of the indistinguishably hellish towns of Southern Ontario.

Joey Cifala - Randall "Randy", Club Sleazebag 

The art of performance is a medium I'm constantly trying to find new ways to grow in. It's something as old as mankind, and as a history fan you can see how character tropes overlap each other throughout the ages. It's something that informs even a ridiculous character like Randy, who is all too relatable in today's world which glorifies sleeze

Christian Milanovic - Crispin, Club Prankster 

Christian enjoys pretending to do things. So we filmed him and everything worked well from there.

Jared Aronoff (also the First Assistant Director and Script Editor) - Toby-Keith, Unknown

On the topic of "who is Jared Aronoff?" it is absolutely imperative that one include the name Toby-Keith in conversation, as there is no Jared Aronoff without Toby-Keith. Vice versa, however, is not the same. Toby-Keith, in question, is an indescribable, divine essence, that transcends this very realm. His very Being is a force that, if we must describe for describings sake, is best described as a phenomenon. Toby-Keith is an experience, a phenomenon, that is best honoured in the very flesh that is reality. Note: should you ever have the pleasure of engaging with Toby-Keith in person we plead you not to question why he never takes off his leather gloves.

What We Need & What You Get

Shooting Location Fee - $400

  • The location we are shooting at requests $25/hour. We have planned two shooting days consisting of 8-9 hours each day. 

Transportation for Crew and Actors: $400

  • We are set to shoot our Pilot episode in Kingston, ON. Many of our crew members and actors will be travelling in from Toronto. 

Food to Feed Cast and Crew - $200

  • With a crew and cast of over 12 people on each shooting day, we need to make sure everyone is well fed and looked after! Food is very important part of creating a happy set! Hanger is a real thing...

Design (props, costumes, set decoration) - $100

  • The characters in the story are represented by their belongings, assets and the regal setting in which they inhabit. We will also be going through quite a bit of de-alcoholized wine. 

Equipment - $100

  • We are aiming to use as much filming equipment as we can that our director of photography already has but we will likely have to rent sound equipment and additional lighting. 

Marketing and Perk Creations - $100

  • To reel you in, we need to make some paraphernalia to impress you! These creations will be exclusive to our 'Turtleneck' campaign and you can have these tangible goodies forever! 

Any left-over donations will be added to The Turtleneck Society Fund which will go towards shooting more episodes as we intend on having an entire first season written and ready to shoot!

Thank You, Merci, Tak Skal Du Have

We are so thankful for all forms of contribution you decide to make, whether it’s by donating, spreading the word, etc. Whatever it is. Thank you. For all your support! 

If there are any other ways you feel you can support other than by donation we’d be so grateful and we welcome you to reach out to us at theturtlenecksociety@gmail.com

Make sure to SHARE the campaign with your family and friends. Follow the show on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. We’re excited to hear from you!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TheTurtleneckSociety/

Instagram: @TheTurtleneckSociety

Twitter: https://twitter.com/TurtleneckShow?lang=en

Please email us at theturtlenecksociety@gmail.com if you have any further questions, comments and concerns and say “Yes!” to The Turtleneck Society and become a member today!

Thanks so much,

The ‘Turtleneck Team’!

As an actor, I chew only the finest of scenery, which is why this project with its particularly delicious setting is so obviously appealing. I treat this endeavour not only as a reflection of myself, but equally of the carefully chosen diet that has crossed my perfectionist palette. Thanks to the efforts of the cast and crew to bring my stories to life, I feel confident that you will be enraptured and enlightened
Fenton Isaacs - Director of Photography 

I'm Fenton and I will be the cinematographer for The Turtleneck Society Web Series. I'm excited to capture the elegance, the grace and the beauty of these characters in a picturesque way. Not only am I excited about making this series look great but I'm also stoked to work on the comedy aspect. How to translate the humour in the script and onto the screen and how to shoot this in a way that reflects the prestige of the club and how they wish others to see them but also who they really are at their core which is superficial, insecure, ridiculous and flawed. 
Jordana Green - Production Designer/Illustrator

Jordana’s ideal turtleneck would be one that can be worn while consuming copious amounts of coffee. Its colour would match, or at the very least complement the colour in an artistic way. When at Queen’s University, the lack of properly coordinated coffee-clothing combinations concerned her. Being in the art department of The Turtleneck Society as production designer is a far more comfortable position in this respect, and the lack of appalling exposed necks is just a bonus.
Danielle Bolick - Lead Animator/Illustrator 

Every time I wear a turtleneck, it feels like a noose is tightening just a little more around my neck; thereby bringing me closer to death. As a masochistic individual, that sweet and deadly embrace comforts me.
As an animator I wanna be famous, but like how voice actors or authors are famous. I wanna be able to go to conventions and sign stuff and meet people that are way cooler than me but somehow like my work and feel famous but then drive out to Robertitos taco shop for lunch in my Nissan Cube and not have anybody recognize me as I scarf down my chicken burrito and spill hot sauce on my shirt. Animating for The Turtleneck Society, and bringing these characters to life, gave me absolute joy. It was the closest thing I could be to being in front of the camera without having to actually be in front of the camera. Also the free wine was some good quality stuff. Thanks y’all!
Jason Fung - Music Supervisor 

Hello! My name is Jason Fung, and I am in charge of music for The Turtleneck Web Series. The decision to record a soundtrack of entirely classical music for piano has been an interesting challenge for me. One wants to find something that will ironically embody the 'hoity-toitiness' of the club, yet provide a pleasant and varied listening experience with the inclusion of a few 'not-quite-so-popular favorites'. This has all been a terrifically fun experience for me, and I hope you will find the series to your liking.
Maria Vlasova - Unit Publicist 

Dear Maria,
As you embark on the journey of being Unit Publicist on The Turtleneck Society, you should remember the experiences you’ve encountered in this great journey of life. Be it as a graduate from Queen’s University, a socials Guru at Wax, or that time you spilled the sunflower oil and had to settle for tequila. You have matured like a fine wine, and now it is time to savour the oaky undertones that you have imbued into your position.
Sincerely,
Maria from the future
Meet the (real life) Turtleneck Society
Gregory Guevara - Alain Improviste,The President 


Existential dread is a humorous thing -- one day your mind screams "AHHHHHH!" and the next it barely musters an "aHhHhHhHh?" When I'm not drowning in the pain of existence I drown instead on the finest of wines. Not out of desire to escape the pain, you understand, but because I genuinely don't like wine. The bitter taste makes my lips tense up and frown involuntarily and in turn furthers my own bitterness towards the world. Why did I pay $80 for this high-class drink I don't even enjoy? I drink the wine out of self-loathing. Haha, just kidding! That was just a bit of a taste of my poetry. I'm really quite a happy person. I play a fellow with some slammin' poetry: the president of the Turtleneck Society. Grab some wine and enjoy. Or don't, the void is indifferent.
Jackson Fielding - Søren von Sørenson, Cultural Attaché


A turtleneck was never something I enjoyed nor sought in my life. Clunky, itchy and often too warm, I made a conscious choice throughout my young life to avoid, shun and on occasions lambaste. It wasn't until I was forcibly gifted a turtleneck that I begrudgingly began to wear them. And while now, three years later, much of that original scorn remains, I put up with it because that's what an artist does. And yes, I am an artist. Not in the literal sense, but the metaphorical. I learnt what 'metaphorical' meant at Queen's university where I went to school and where this whole turtleneck trouble began. And here we are now, making something explicitly centered around the turtleneck top. That's okay, I suppose.
Alexandra Lloyd - Elizabeth "Lizzie", Club Photographer 

Alexandra Lloyd, playing the role of Lizzie, could not be more excited to be a part of such a wonderful project! As someone living on a university student’s budget, Alexandra is looking forward to portraying a character who is a true bougie-ass b*tch. In addition for her passion for the arts, Alexandra loves ranting about the cisheteropatriarchy and using the third person to discuss herself. Alexandra currently resides in one of the indistinguishably hellish towns of Southern Ontario.
Joey Cifala - Randall "Randy", Club Sleazebag 

The art of performance is a medium I'm constantly trying to find new ways to grow in. It's something as old as mankind, and as a history fan you can see how character tropes overlap each other throughout the ages. It's something that informs even a ridiculous character like Randy, who is all too relatable in today's world which glorifies sleeze
Christian Milanovic - Crispin, Club Prankster 

Christian enjoys pretending to do things. So we filmed him and everything worked well from there.
Jared Aronoff (also the First Assistant Director and Script Editor) - Toby-Keith, Unknown


On the topic of "who is Jared Aronoff?" it is absolutely imperative that one include the name Toby-Keith in conversation, as there is no Jared Aronoff without Toby-Keith. Vice versa, however, is not the same. Toby-Keith, in question, is an indescribable, divine essence, that transcends this very realm. His very Being is a force that, if we must describe for describings sake, is best described as a phenomenon. Toby-Keith is an experience, a phenomenon, that is best honoured in the very flesh that is reality. Note: should you ever have the pleasure of engaging with Toby-Keith in person we plead you not to question why he never takes off his leather gloves.
What We Need & What You Get

Shooting Location Fee - $400
The location we are shooting at requests $25/hour. We have planned two shooting days consisting of 8-9 hours each day. 
Transportation for Crew and Actors: $400
We are set to shoot our Pilot episode in Kingston, ON. Many of our crew members and actors will be travelling in from Toronto. 
Food to Feed Cast and Crew - $200
With a crew and cast of over 12 people on each shooting day, we need to make sure everyone is well fed and looked after! Food is very important part of creating a happy set! Hanger is a real thing...
Design (props, costumes, set decoration) - $100
The characters in the story are represented by their belongings, assets and the regal setting in which they inhabit. We will also be going through quite a bit of de-alcoholized wine. 
Equipment - $100
We are aiming to use as much filming equipment as we can that our director of photography already has but we will likely have to rent sound equipment and additional lighting. 
Marketing and Perk Creations - $100
To reel you in, we need to make some paraphernalia to impress you! These creations will be exclusive to our 'Turtleneck' campaign and you can have these tangible goodies forever! 
Any left-over donations will be added to The Turtleneck Society Fund which will go towards shooting more episodes as we intend on having an entire first season written and ready to shoot!

Thank You, Merci, Tak Skal Du Have
We are so thankful for all forms of contribution you decide to make, whether it’s by donating, spreading the word, etc. Whatever it is. Thank you. For all your support! 
If there are any other ways you feel you can support other than by donation we’d be so grateful and we welcome you to reach out to us at theturtlenecksociety@gmail.com
Make sure to SHARE the campaign with your family and friends. Follow the show on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter. We’re excited to hear from you!
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TheTurtleneckSociety/
Instagram: @TheTurtleneckSociety
Twitter: https://twitter.com/TurtleneckShow?lang=en
Please email us at theturtlenecksociety@gmail.com if you have any further questions, comments and concerns and say “Yes!” to The Turtleneck Society and become a member today!
Thanks so much,
The ‘Turtleneck Team’!

story:
Short Summary

All 6 episodes of The Bachelor: Princess Edition mini-series are in the can and YOU got it there. We can't thank you enough for getting us through Pre-Production and Production. With the funds from our first Indiegogo we were able to film in a beautiful location fit for a Prince Bachelor, cast Princess contestants with stunning Disneybound outfits, hire the best possible crew to get us through all 6 episodes in only 2 short days at the mansion, purchase insurance needed for the location, feed the cast/crew, and provide all the lights, filming equipment, sound recording equipment, props, make-up, set dec, and costume changes needed. 

Even though our footage looks AMAZING (seriously, we could not be more ecstatic with the footage), it's not ready to be released yet. We didn't raise all of the money we needed to complete the project in our first Indiegogo, so we need your help again to get it through Post Production and onto YouTube. We were $2,000 shy of our goal the first time around and that was delegated to the budget for Post Production. Read on to find out what that entails. 

What We Need & What You Get

Now that we have all the gorgeous footage from filming, we need to be able to put it together in a way that will highlight the high production value we always strive for in our parody videos. We are able to edit a rough cut of the footage together ourselves; however, we need to pay others to use their unique skills and equipment to make it look and sound professional. In order for you as the viewer to be sucked in and not distracted by the harsh cuts between scenes, we will have a COMPOSER provide special transition music as well as sound effects that you would expect on a cheesy reality show. He will also MIX THE SOUND of characters’ voices so that there are no dramatic shifts in volume or tone, which can sometimes happen when cutting together shots that were filmed in different rooms with completely different acoustics. Also, since we filmed this series on two separate cameras (which is a glorious thing, we must say!), the coloring of each shot is going to look pretty different. We will need to spend a small chunk of this goal on having someone COLOR CORRECT THE FOOTAGE so that the color matches in each scene.

Above is an example of footage from uncolored footage (on left) and colored footage (on right)

Another comparison of the uncolored footage (on top) & colored footage (on bottom)

The last thing we need to account for is ADVERTISING this web series. While it is always a huge help to have backers and friends share our projects on social media, it is essential for us to be able to promote to more far-reaching audiences in order to get the views we think this deserves. We want all the dedication and hard work that every cast and crew member put into this production to be recognized all over the world, which is very possible already through YouTube. We just need that extra push from paid advertisements and press releases to get more viewers who haven’t yet discovered our channel.

 In summary, The Bachelor: Princess Edition still needs:

  • COLOR CORRECTION
  • MUSICAL COMPOSITION 
  • SOUND EDITING
  • ADVERTISING

WHAT YOU GET:

  • This time the perks are even more unique and exciting. We're giving away things like PROPS and COSTUMES we already used in the filming of the series, Invitations to our private screening & wrap party, Your Name listed in the credits, and so much more! 
  • If we don't reach our entire goal this time around, we will release the episodes this Indiegogo is able to cover. For example, if we raise enough only to release 3 episodes, we'll release those 3 episodes, and try fundraising again for the last 3. We won't give up until the entire series is available for everyone to see! Trust us, it won't disappoint! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We get that not everyone can contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help! 

  • We need to get the word out and spread some noise about this 2nd campaign!
  • Indiegogo has share tools that are super easy to use! 
  • Reach out to people individually who you think may be interested in this project and share this page for a more broad approach on your social media platforms - you never know who you know that might be interested!

We need to get the word out and spread some noise about this 2nd campaign!
Indiegogo has share tools that are super easy to use! 
Reach out to people individually who you think may be interested in this project and share this page for a more broad approach on your social media platforms - you never know who you know that might be interested!

story:
SYNOPSIS

Amy is managing the strategy on her biggest account- an Australian company run by #girlboss Andrea. Andrea’s company is replacing the dull, uninventive portable coffee mug with 'Coffee Boottle' a trendalicious baby bottle. It’s all the rage in Asian coffee shops. They’ve hired THE Agency to help them enter the North American market. Can Amy keep her biggest client happy while juggling all her other responsibilities?

A little bit Marty Khan à la House of Lies. A little bit of Ally McBeal à la Ally McBeal. A little bit Peggy Olson à la Mad Men. A whole lot of ridiculous!

Serious topic matters include: Burnout & Sexism 

Our main client in Season One is a 'Coffee Bottle'.

Where Your $ Goes 

Your donation will go directly into our productions cost. Even though this a shoe-string budget web series, we still have costs. They include:

  • Location fees
  • Equipment Rentals (camera gear, sound, lighting, etc)
  • UBCP Insurance to cover actors in the union
  • Props
  • Graphic Design & Photography
  • Promotion - Advertising to promote the web series, fees for entry into festivals 
  • Crafty- ie FEEDING unpaid people on set
  • If extra $$$ is raised it will go into ensuring an even higher production value 

80% of our PERKS are digital because we don't think the world needs more stuff. 

If we reach our goal of $3000, I will personally donate $200 OUTSIDE of the budget to the BC Cancer Foundation. 

The TEAM 

Alina Anghel - Creator & Actor 

Devon Mussett - Director

Rowan Jang - Producer

Check out our cast in the image gallery!

Getting VIEWS

Not only are we creating a web series about marketing agencies, but some of us have worked at them! Our web series will get the added boost of ad dollars to help drive viewership. Plus we're counting on a niche target market that works at agencies to connect with the hilarity of the content. Also helps that the hashtag #AgencyLife has 1.2 million posts on Insta ;). 

FOLLOW US ON INSTA: @hashtagagencylife
